docs.lead_paragraph: Barbara Kingsolver has been hospitable beyond the call of duty ever since I accidentally arrived early at her house in Tucson and surprised her padding barefoot in a sundress and sipping a beer. She's been solicitous about jet lag. She has gone out into her woolly desert garden, plucked giant cucumbers and bright purple eggplants and cooked up a delicious meal. But when I ask about her childhood, she says, ''I'm not crazy about myself,'' and emits a low, edgy chuckle. Kingsolver, you see, doesn't want to be just another late-20th-century image for sale. She's no performer, and the history of her psyche is not in the public domain. When I suggest that Dickens, Twain and Wilde all happily embraced fame, she counters: ''Well, they weren't raising kids. And Oscar Wilde was never shoved onto the noontime news in Denver and a mike clipped to his lapel and asked, 'In 58 seconds, because that's what we have, what did you mean when you wrote ''The Importance of Being Earnest?'' '
docs.abstract: Sarah Kerr interview with Barbara Kingsolver in her Tucson home about her new book, The Poisonwood Bible; photos; novel, Kingsolver's first in five years, is tragic family saga set in Congo in late 1950's and early 1960's, but also aims to expose American role in assassination of Patrica Lumumba and installation of dictator Mobutu; Kingsolver discusses political and social activism which has led her to endow new literary prize, the Bellwether, to be awarded to writer of an unpublished novel that addresses issues of 'social change' (M)
